text: I think it's in mourning and Melancholia
that Freud said something
about
melancholics having a unique perspective
on civilization but at what cost you
know and that's sort of my experience
too
that the unhappier parts of my
career enabled me to say the more
trenching things perhaps but I'm not
satisfied with the sort of
psychic economics of that
because if I'm not happy enough to
finish the book or too miserable to be
able to want to do my job it doesn't
matter what truths I'm capable of uh
scaring up in my brain at that time I
don't know why it is
exactly um that creativity and
depression go hand
inand but I'm sort of happy that they do
in so far as that there has to be
someone who's able to stand enough
outside of civilization to comment on it
maybe it's just a kind of Exile you know
when when Joyce says silence Exile and
cunning are the ways to become a great
artist and in portrait of the Artist as
a Young
Man I take the Exile part to heart you
need to be able to sit outside a little
bit to to look clearly at at what's
happening but that also presupposed is
that you're
not in society and thus not part of its
happy
throngs I was talking to Mary gateskill
about this the novelist Mary
gateskill and we were particularly
discussing the suppression of libido in
contemporary anti-depressant medication
and her theory was that you had to be
sad a little bit in order to have great
sex so the two go hand inand as you
suppress the sadness you also suppress
the sexual impulse in some way and you
sort of go contentedly along in life
incapable incapable of the most
passionate moments you know and it's
possible that something similar happens
to to Art if you sort of have everybody
operating at this contented mean you uh
don't enable the sorts of outrage or the
kinds of
um passionate enthusiasm that make
important art happen I mean I I suspect
I've never been on Prozac or any of
those kinds of medications but I suspect
that people who are who are still enjoy
great art and are perfectly capable of
liking a great novel no matter how
challenging it is you know and they
would say that that's not that their
medication is not interruptive of of
that experience but then how does it
work for the people who make it you know
David Wallace is perhaps an
example you know I think his depression
enabled him to be the great artist that
he was it also was perhaps the thing
that killed him you know but it's also
true that he was unable to finish a
novel After Infinite just and he was on
medication for a while so who knows
maybe there's some connection there
